Article.ArticleTitle: Variations in leaf anatomical characteristics drive the decrease of mesophyll conductance in poplar under elevated ozone.

AbstractText: Decline in mesophyll conductance (g<sub>m</sub> ) plays a key role in limiting photosynthesis in plants exposed to elevated ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ). Leaf anatomical traits are known to influence g<sub>m</sub> , but the potential effects of O<sub>3</sub> -induced changes in leaf anatomy on g<sub>m</sub> have not yet been clarified. Here, two poplar clones were exposed to elevated O<sub>3</sub> . The effects of O<sub>3</sub> on the photosynthetic capacity and anatomical characteristics were assessed to investigate the leaf anatomical properties that potentially affect g<sub>m</sub> . We also conducted global meta-analysis to explore the general response patterns of g<sub>m</sub> and leaf anatomy to O<sub>3</sub> exposure. We found that the O<sub>3</sub> -induced reduction in g<sub>m</sub> was critical in limiting leaf photosynthesis. Changes in liquid-phase conductance rather than gas-phase conductance drive the decline in g<sub>m</sub> under elevated O<sub>3,</sub> and this effect was associated with thicker cell walls and smaller chloroplast sizes. The effects of O<sub>3</sub> on palisade and spongy mesophyll cell traits and their contributions to g<sub>m</sub> were highly genotype-dependent. Our results suggest that, while anatomical adjustments under elevated O<sub>3</sub> may contribute to defense against O<sub>3</sub> stress, they also cause declines in g<sub>m</sub> and photosynthesis. These results provide the first evidence of anatomical constraints on g<sub>m</sub> under elevated O<sub>3</sub> .
